May 14<br>http://bit.ly/1xWMG1d<br><br>Grassroots Community Meeting 5 Includes Rare Screening Of 'Blacks<br>Britannica'<br><br>Sunday, 22 March 2015, 2-5pm<br><br>To book: http://bit.ly/1wJA6UT<br><br>This fifth Grassroots Community Meeting is to discuss what gains Black<br>(African &amp; Asian) people have made within British society viz a viz race and<br>class, 50 years after their struggles and activism along with support from<br>progressive factions led to the enactment of the 1965 Race Relations Act<br> [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T08:45:07-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>msherwood</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BASA;de78aa80.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BASA;351c81a4.1503">   <title>TATE & LYLE </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BASA;351c81a4.1503</link>   <description> The Presentation: TATE &amp; LYLE - SUGAR &amp; SLAVERY opens another chapter on Emancipation. After the liberation of nearly a million enslaved Africans, British businessmen ensured that the price of raw sugar from the British Caribbean remained below 1830s levels for the following 70 years. Those 19th century decades saw gigantic profits for British sugar refinery businessmen, but declining wages (below one shillings a day) for both African and Asian plantation workers. Emigration from the colonies was an option for some families.<br>You are invited to the following event: WINDRUSH FOUNDATION Presents TATE & LYLE - SUGAR & SLAVERY Event [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T06:49:33+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>arthur torrington</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BASA;351c81a4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BASA;3e854f47.1503">   <title>Re: Black and Minority Ethnic (BME) Education resources LibGuide </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=BASA;3e854f47.1503</link>   <description> I thought the British Library (Andy Simmons?) had published a list of<br>books..<br><br>From: The Black and Asian Studies Association [mailto:BASA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK]<br>On Behalf Of Emma Allison<br>Sent: 10 March 2015 10:33<br>To: BASA@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: Black and Minority Ethnic (BME) Education resources LibGuide<br><br>Good morning everyone,<br><br>I have created a library guide (LibGuide) to try to raise awareness of BME<br>education- issues, resources, etc- which I am hopeful you can help me with.<br>I don't think I have half of the amazing stuff out there listed. (Indeed, the name 'Athena' was a particularly unhelpful choice, in this regard. Cf. the white backlash over 'Black Athena': http://athenatrickster.blogspot.co.uk/2014/10/putting-athena-into-black-athena.html) You need to advance public understanding of the intersectional nature of social oppression.
